questions.question: Question 1: Which is the first bone to ossify in the human body?
questions.explanation:
The clavicle is the first bone to ossify in the human body. It occurs by the 5th- 6th weeks of 
intrauterine life. The clavicle is a band of condensed mesenchyme in the early embryonic phase. At the terminal ends of this band, early cartilage transformation (pre-cartilage) takes place. 
Intramembranous centers of ossification appear and fuse in the mesenchyme between them. 
Hence, it ossifies partly in the membrane and partly in cartilage.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is false about clavicle?

options.a: Ossify partly in membrane and partly in cartilage
options.b: Transmits part of the weight of upper limb to the axial skeleton
options.c: It is subcutaneous throughout its length
options.d: Fractures typically occur at the junction of medial 1/3rd and lateral 2/3rd

questions.explanation:
Fractures of the clavicle typically occur at the junction of the medial 3/5 th and lateral 2/5 th. Middle-third or midshaft region of the clavicle is the most common site for a fracture, especially 
the junction of medial 3/5 th and lateral 2/5 th. 626 
Sold by @itachibot It is the junction where the 2 primary ossification centers meet. It is also where the transition 
from antecurve to retro curve begins and is prone to be at high risk for fractures. The fracture causes the upward displacement of the proximal fragment (sternocleidomastoid) and 
downward displacement of the distal fragment (pectoralis major and gravity).

questions.question: Question 3: Which ligament transmits the weight of the upper limb to the axial skeleton?
questions.explanation:
The weight of the upper limb is transmitted to the axial skeleton by coracoclavicular and 
costoclavicular ligament. The weight of the upper limb is transmitted as follows: Upper limb  coracoclavicular ligament  clavicle  costoclavicular ligament  axial skeleton 
(sternum and 1st rib) Manubrium sterni  Sternoclavicular ligament  clavicle. 627 
Sold by @itachibot Note: • Costoclavicular ligament: Transmits weight of the upper limb to the axial skeleton via the 
clavicle. • Coracoclavicular ligament: Transmits weight of the upper limb to the clavicle. • Sternoclavicular ligament : Transmits weight of the upper limb to axial skeleton via clavicle 
(inferomedially)

questions.question:
Question 4: In a patient with a coracoid fracture, the action of which of the following muscle is not 
hindered?
questions.explanation:
In a patient with a coracoid fracture, the action of the long head of triceps muscle is not hindered. 
It attaches to the infraglenoid tubercle on the lateral border of the scapula and not the coracoid 
process. Coracoid process attachements: • Origin: 2 muscles - Coracobrachialis (medially) and short head of biceps (laterally) • Insertion: 1 muscle - Pectoralis minor • 3 ligaments: • Coracoacromial • Coracoclavicular • Coracohumeral

questions.question:
Question 5: A 16-year-old athlete was diagnosed with an isolated avulsion fracture of the lesser tubercle of 
the humerus. The forceful contraction of which of the following muscles■ causes this 
fracture?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, forceful contraction of the subscapularis muscle has caused the 
isolated avulsion fracture of the lesser tubercle of the humerus. 628 
Sold by @itachibot The subscapularis muscle is inserted on the lesser tubercle of the humerus. Forceful contraction of 
subscapularis muscle to resist the abduction and external rotation of the shoulder may cause the 
isolated avulsion fracture of the lesser tubercle. Rotator cuff muscles Muscle 
Insertion Greater tubercl 
e S: Supraspinat 
us I: Infraspinatu 
s T: Teres Minor Lesser tubercle S: Subscapular 
is

questions.question: Question 6: Which muscle is attached to the floor of the structure marked A?
questions.explanation:
The structure marked A is the intertubercular sulcus (bicipital groove) and the latissimus dorsi is 
attached to its floor. The intertubercular sulcus (bicipital groove) lies between the greater and lesser tubercles. 629 
Sold by @itachibot The attachments of bicipital groove are as follows: • Lateral lip: Pectoralis major • Medial lip: Teres major • Floor: Latissimus dorsi The contents of the sulcus are as follows: • Long head of the biceps • ascending branch from the anterior circumflex humeral artery MEMORY TIP: Remember 'Lady between two majors': The lady (latissimsus dorsi), in the intertubercular sulcus, 
lies between the pectoralis major laterally, and teres major medially.

questions.question:
Question 7: 620 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following types of joints is incorrectly matched?

options.d: Intercarpal and midcarpal joint – Plane synovial joint

questions.explanation:
The sternoclavicular joint is a synovial sellar (saddle, or hyperbolic paraboloid) joint, and not a 
hinge joint. It is the only skeletal articulation between the upper limb and the axial skeleton. 630 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: A 25-year-old man comes with sudden pain in his right shoulder. He complains that he is not 
able to move his right arm. After evaluation, a diagnosis of shoulder dislocation was made. 
Which of the following statements is false regarding this joint?

options.a: The glenohumeral joint is the most frequently dislocated joint in the body
options.b: As mobility of the joint increases, stability also increases
options.c: The shoulder joint dislocation is rare in children
options.d: Anterior dislocation is more common than a posterior dislocation

questions.explanation:
As mobility increases, stability is lost in a joint. The glenohumeral joint is the most mobile joint in 
the body and is very unstable. The glenohumeral joint is the most frequently dislocated joint in the body. The shoulder 
dislocation occurs more commonly in adults and is rare in children. Anterior dislocation is much 
more common than a posterior dislocation.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 17-year-old boy presented with instability of the shoulder joint following sports trauma. 
Injury to all of the following structures may cause this condition except:

options.c: Tendon of long head of biceps

questions.explanation:
Teres major has no role in maintaining the stability of the shoulder joint. The shoulder joint is a ball and socket joint. Since the head of the humerus is larger than the 
glenoid cavity, it is often prone to displacement. However, the stability of the shoulder joint is 
provided by the following: • Rotator cuff: It is formed by blending of tendons of 4 muscles (SITS)- • Supraspinatus • Infraspinatus • Teres minor • Subscapularis • Tendon of the long head of biceps: It passes over the head of the humerus and prevents upward 
displacement. • Coracoacromial ligament Degeneration or tear of the above structures leads to instability of the shoulder joint. 631 
Sold by @itachibot The shoulder joint is least protected inferiorly. The capsule is loose and only one muscle crosses 
the joint inferiorly, i.e. long head of triceps.

questions.question: Question 10: In a patient with shoulder dislocation, which of the following muscle action is not hindered?
questions.explanation:
Pectoralis minor has no action at the shoulder joint. Its origin is from 3,4,5 ribs near the costochondral junction and inserts at the medial border and 
the upper surface of the coracoid process. The pectoralis minor is an accessory muscle of 
inspiration, which stabilizes the scapula by pulling it anteriorly and inferiorly. Movements at the shoulder joint: Movement 
Prime Movers 
Synergists Flexion

questions.question:
Question 11: Which movement range is increased at the glenohumeral joint due to the lateral rotation of 
the humerus?
questions.explanation:
Lateral rotation of the humerus increases the range of abduction. When the arm is abducted without rotation, the greater tubercle comes in contact with the 
coracoacromial arch, preventing further abduction. If the arm is then laterally rotated 180°, the tubercles are rotated posteriorly and the more 
articular surface becomes available to continue elevation. Hence, the range of abduction is 
increased.

questions.question: Question 12: A normal scapulohumeral rhythm is in the ratio of
questions.explanation:
A normal scapulohumeral rhythm is in the ratio of 2:1. Scapulohumeral rhythm is the ratio of the glenohumeral movement to the scapulothoracic 
movement during arm elevation. 632 
Sold by @itachibot For instance, if the arm is abducted to a 90° angle, the glenohumeral elevation is 60° and the 
scapulothoracic rotation is 30°. Thus, the humerus and scapula move in a 2:1 ratio.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following structure is intracapsular?
questions.explanation:
The long head of biceps is intracapsular. The fibrous capsule which envelopes the shoulder joint is attached medially to the glenoid neck at 
a variable distance from the glenoid labrum. The capsule includes the supraglenoid tubercle, to 
which the long head of the biceps attaches, and which is therefore intracapsular.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following muscles form the border of rotator interval?
questions.explanation:
Rotator interval is an area between the supraspinatus and subscapularis. The rotator interval is a medially-based, triangular area that is not covered by the capsule. 633 
Sold by @itachibot It is present between the superior edge of the subscapularis and the anterior edge of 
the supraspinatus with the coracoid as the medial boundary of the interval. It is reinforced by the 
coracohumeral ligament, the superior glenohumeral ligament, and fibers from the supraspinatus 
tendon laterally.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following structures of the scapula is palpable in the infraclavicular fossa?
questions.explanation:
The part of the scapula marked as "A" in this image is palpable and it is the coracoid process. The apex of the coracoid process lies approximately 2.5cm below the clavicle, immediately lateral 
to the infraclavicular fossa (deltopectoral triangle). Hence, the coracoid process can be palpated 
below the clavicle. 634 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 16: Movements of pronation and supination occurs in all of the following joints except:
questions.explanation:
Prono-supination movements do not happen at the radiocarpal (wrist) joint. Supination and pronation mainly occur at 3 joints: • Humeroradial • Superior radioulnar joints • Inferior radioulnar joints The middle radioulnar joint is a syndesmosis (fibrous) joint that mainly helps bind the radius and 
ulna together. It also helps in weight transmission from radius towards ulna.

questions.question: Question 17: During an intracapsular arthroscopy, which of the following structure cannot be seen?
questions.explanation:
During the intracapsular arthroscopy, the lateral epicondyle is not seen since it is extracapsular. The capsular ligament of the elbow joint is attached anteriorly just above the coronoid and radial 
fossa and posteriorly above the olecranon fossa. Note: Medial epicondyle is also extracapsular.

questions.question: Question 18: What is the normal approximate carrying angle?
questions.explanation:
The average carrying angle is approximately 17°. The carrying angle is the angle defined by the border of the fully supinated forearm and the long 
axis of the humerus when the elbow is fully extended. It is usually 10°-15° in males and more than 15° in females. The absolute angle varies from 
individual to individual and also increases as age increases. 635 
Sold by @itachibot In clinics, it's necessary to see the carrying angle of the contralateral side instead of just on a 
single side. But anything between 5 to 15 degrees is considered normal. The carrying angle is used 
to identify varus or valgus in the elbow joint. It decreases in cubitus varus and increases in cubitus 
valgus.

questions.question: Question 19: The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a:
questions.explanation:
The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a fibrous joint (syndesmosis). The radius and ulna are united with each other by three joints: • Proximal (superior) radioulnar joint • Middle radioulnar joint • Distal (inferior) radioulnar joint 636 
Sold by @itachibot Proximal and distal radioulnar joints are uniaxial pivot joints (synovial) and are involved in 
pronation and supination movements of the forearm. The middle radioulnar joint is a fibrous joint (syndesmosis). The radius and ulna, in the middle, 
are connected by two syndesmoses namely: • The oblique cord - extends from the lateral side of the ulnar tuberosity to the radius, distal to the 
radial tuberosity. • Interosseous membrane - a broad, thin collagenous structure, which runs perpendicular to the 
oblique cord. It extends distomedially between the interosseous borders of the radius and ulna. Based on the structure, joints are classified into three types: • Fibrous joints • Sutures • Syndesmosis • Gomphosis • Cartilaginous joints • Primary cartilaginous joints or synchondrosis • Secondary cartilaginous joints or symphysis • Synovial joints • Ball-and-socket or spheroidal joints • Sellar or saddle joints • Condylar or bicondylar joints • Ellipsoid joints • Hinge joints • Pivot or trochoid joints • Plane joints 637 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 20: A golfer hurt himself after he accidentally hit the ground while taking a shot. He has 
tenderness in the area shown in the image below. On examination, he has pain radiating to 
his ring and little finger. Which of the following bones is most likely to be fractured? 624 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
In the above scenario, the area of tenderness and the pain in the ring and little finger are 
suggestive of the hook of hamate fracture. The pain in the ring and little finger is related to the 
close proximity of the ulnar nerve which could get affected due to a fracture of hook of hamate. The hamate is cuneiform and bears an unciform hamulus (hook) that projects from the distal part 
of its rough palmar surface. Mnemonic for Carpal Bones - She(S) - Scaphoid Looks(L) - Lunate 638 
Sold by @itachibot Too(T) - Triquetral Pretty(P) - Pisiform Try (T) - Trapezium To(T) - Trapezoid Catch(C) - Capitate Her(H) - Hamate

questions.question:
Question 21: A child falls from his bicycle and injures his hand. On X-ray, a fracture of the first metacarpal 
bone is noticed. Where is the epiphysis of the affected bone?
questions.explanation:
The epiphysis of the first metacarpal is present at the base. All the other metacarpals have 
epiphysis at the head. Features of the first metacarpal: • Epiphysis at the head is an aberrant epiphysis • It is the shortest and stoutest of all metacarpals • The palmar (medial) surface is longitudinally concave and divided by a ridge into a larger lateral 
(anterior) and smaller medial (posterior) part • The base has a convexo-concave articular surface to make a saddle synovial joint with trapezium The first metacarpal fracture at the base of the thumb is called Bennett's fracture. It is 
an intraarticular fracture that separates the palmar ulnar aspect of the base of the first metacarpal 
from the rest of the first metacarpal. The image below shows a radiograph of a hand at 2.5 years (dorsopalmar projection). Note the 
early stages of ossification in the epiphyses at the proximal ends (base) of the phalanges and first 
metacarpal; the distal ends of the remaining metacarpals and radius. 639 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 22: All of the following take part in the formation of the wrist joint, except:
questions.explanation:
The distal end of the ulna does not take part in the formation of the radiocarpal joint. The radiocarpal joint (Wrist joint) is a synovial, biaxial, and ellipsoid joint formed by the 
articulation of: • The distal end of the radius • Articular disc of the triangular fibrocartilage • Scaphoid, lunate and triquetrum In the neutral position of the wrist, only the scaphoid and lunate are in contact with the radius 
and articular disc; the triquetrum comes into apposition with the disc only in full adduction of the 
wrist joint. 640 
Sold by @itachibot Fossae and Spaces of the Upper Limb
